articles.headline: Google and Friends to Gang Up on Facebook
articles.snippet: An alliance of companies led by Google plans to roll out a common set of standards to allow developers to write programs for Google’s Orkut and other social networking Web sites.
articles.abstract: An alliance of companies led by Google plans to roll out a common set of standards to allow developers to write programs for Google’s Orkut and other social networking Web sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 — Google and some of the Web’s leading social networks are teaming up to take on the new kid on the block — Facebook.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Merrill Chooses Insider to Lead Search for Chief
articles.snippet: As Merrill Lynch begins to search for its next chief executive, the company named Alberto Cribiore as its nonexecutive chairman and leader of its search committee.
articles.abstract: As Merrill Lynch begins to search for its next chief executive, the company named Alberto Cribiore as its nonexecutive chairman and leader of its search committee.

articles.headline: Online Marketers Joining Internet Privacy Efforts
articles.snippet: People will soon be able to sign up for do-not-track lists, which will help shield their Web surfing habits from marketers eager to deliver specific ad pitches to them.
articles.abstract: People will soon be able to sign up for do-not-track lists, which will help shield their Web surfing habits from marketers eager to deliver specific ad pitches to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most consumers are familiar with do-not-call lists, which are meant to keep telemarketers from phoning them. Soon people will be able to sign up for do-not-track lists, which will help shield their Web surfing habits from the prying eyes of marketers.

articles.headline: Plain Truth About Taxes and Cuts
articles.snippet: There are some basic facts about taxes in the U.S. that ideology can’t change, and if you keep these in mind, you will have an easier time keeping up with the debate.
articles.abstract: There are some basic facts about taxes in the U.S. that ideology can’t change, and if you keep these in mind, you will have an easier time keeping up with the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’re going to hear a lot about taxes over the next two years. Some of the things you hear will be true. Others will be less true. The goal here today is distinguish between the two.

articles.headline: Hello, India? I Need Help With My Math
articles.snippet: In a new wave of global outsourcing, personal chores are moving offshore, and this is leading to some daunting challenges, both economic and cultural.
articles.abstract: In a new wave of global outsourcing, personal chores are moving offshore, and this is leading to some daunting challenges, both economic and cultural.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adrianne Yamaki, a 32-year-old management consultant in New York, travels constantly and logs 80-hour workweeks. So to eke out more time for herself, she routinely farms out the administrative chores of her life — making travel arrangements, hair appointments and restaurant reservations and buying theater tickets — to a personal assistant service, in India.

articles.headline: A Pitched Debate: Clinton Hears It From Her Rivals
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton came under withering attack from the rest of the Democratic field.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton came under withering attack from the rest of the Democratic field.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York came under withering attack from the rest of the Democratic presidential field last night in a pitched two-hour debate that her opponents used to challenge her candor and electability and to portray her as enabling President Bush to prepare for an invasion of Iran.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Chinese Chemicals Flow Unchecked Onto World Drug Market
articles.snippet: Pharmaceutical ingredients exported from China are often made by companies that are neither certified nor inspected by Chinese drug regulators.
articles.abstract: Pharmaceutical ingredients exported from China are often made by companies that are neither certified nor inspected by Chinese drug regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Walt Bogdanich, Jake Hooker and Andrew W. Lehren and written by Mr. Bogdanich.
